metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: PHP OOP - Classes and Objects
A class is a template for objects, and an object is an instance of class.
content.html: A class is a template for objects, and an object is an instance of class.

content.text: OOP Case
Let's assume we have a class named Fruit. A Fruit can have properties like name, color, weight, etc. We can define variables like $name, $color, and $weight to hold the values of these properties.
content.html: Let's assume we have a class named Fruit. A Fruit can have properties like name, color, weight, etc. We can define variables like $name, $color, and $weight to hold the values of these properties.

content.text: When the individual objects (apple, banana, etc.) are created, they inherit all the properties and behaviors from the class, but each object will have different values for the properties.
content.html: When the individual objects (apple, banana, etc.) are created, they inherit all the properties and behaviors from the class, but each object will have different values for the properties.

content.text: Define a Class
A class is defined by using the class keyword, followed by the name of the class and a pair of curly braces ({}). All its properties and methods go inside the braces:
content.html: A class is defined by using the class keyword, followed by the name of the class and a pair of curly braces ({}). All its properties and methods go inside the braces:

content.code_html:
<?php
class Fruit {
  // code goes here...
}
?>

content.text: Below we declare a class named Fruit consisting of two properties ($name and $color) and two methods set_name() and get_name() for setting and getting the $name property:
content.html: Below we declare a class named Fruit consisting of two properties ($name and $color) and two methods set_name() and get_name() for setting and getting the $name property:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?phpclass Fruit {  // Properties  public 
    $name;  public $color;  // Methods  function 
    set_name($name) {    
    $this->name = $name;  }  function get_name() {    
    return $this->name;  }}?>

content.code:
<?phpclass Fruit {  // Properties  public 
$name;  public $color;  // Methods  function
set_name($name) {
$this->name = $name;  }  function get_name() {
return $this->name;  }}?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<?phpclass Fruit {  // Properties  public 
    $name;  public $color;  // Methods  function 
    set_name($name) {    
    $this->name = $name;  }  function get_name() {    
 return $this->name;  }}?>

content.code_html:
<?php
class Fruit {
  // Properties
  public $name;
  public $color;

  // Methods
  function set_name($name) {
    $this->name = $name;
  }
  function get_name() {
    return $this->name;
  }
}
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<?phpclass Fruit {  // Properties  public 
    $name;  public $color;  // Methods  function 
    set_name($name) {    
    $this->name = $name;  }  function get_name() {    
    return $this->name;  }}?>

content.text: Note: In a class, variables are called properties and functions are called methods!
content.html: Note: In a class, variables are called properties and functions are called methods!

content.text: Define Objects
Classes are nothing without objects! We can create multiple objects from a class. Each object has all the properties and methods defined in the class, but they will have different property values.
content.html: Classes are nothing without objects! We can create multiple objects from a class. Each object has all the properties and methods defined in the class, but they will have different property values.

content.text: Objects of a class are created using the new keyword.
content.html: Objects of a class are created using the new keyword.

content.text: In the example below, $apple and $banana are instances of the class Fruit:
content.html: In the example below, $apple and $banana are instances of the class Fruit:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
name = $name;  }  function get_name() {    return $this->name;  }}$apple = new Fruit(); $banana = new Fruit();$apple->set_name('Apple');$banana->set_name('Banana'); echo $apple->get_name();echo "
"; echo $banana->get_name();?>

content.code:
name = $name;  }  function get_name() { return $this->name;  }}$apple = new Fruit(); $banana = new Fruit();$apple->set_name('Apple');$banana->set_name('Banana'); echo $apple->get_name();echo "
"; echo $banana->get_name();?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
name = $name;  }  function get_name() {    return $this->name;  }}$apple = new Fruit(); $banana = new Fruit();$apple->set_name('Apple');$banana->set_name('Banana'); echo $apple->get_name();echo "
"; echo $banana->get_name();?>

content.code_html:
<?php
class Fruit {
  // Properties
  public $name;
  public $color;

  // Methods
  function set_name($name) {
    $this->name = $name;
  }
  function get_name() {
    return $this->name;
  }
}

$apple = new Fruit();
$banana = new Fruit();
$apple->set_name('Apple');
$banana->set_name('Banana');

echo $apple->get_name();
echo "<br>";
echo $banana->get_name();
?>

"; echo $banana->get_name();?>

content.text: In the example below, we add two more methods to class Fruit, for setting and getting the $color property:
content.html: In the example below, we add two more methods to class Fruit, for setting and getting the $color property:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
name = $name;  }  function get_name() {    return $this->name;  }  function set_color($color) {    $this->color = $color;  }  function get_color() {    return $this->color;  } }$apple = new Fruit();$apple->set_name('Apple'); $apple->set_color('Red');echo "Name: " . $apple->get_name();echo "
"; echo "Color: " . $apple->get_color();?>

content.code_html:
<?php
class Fruit {
  // Properties
  public $name;
  public $color;

  // Methods
  function set_name($name) {
    $this->name = $name;
  }
  function get_name() {
    return $this->name;
  }
  function set_color($color) {
    $this->color = $color;
  }
  function get_color() {
    return $this->color;
  }
}

$apple = new Fruit();
$apple->set_name('Apple');
$apple->set_color('Red');
echo "Name: " . $apple->get_name();
echo "<br>";
echo "Color: " . $apple->get_color();
?>

content.text: PHP - The $this Keyword
The $this keyword refers to the current object, and is only available inside methods.
content.html: The $this keyword refers to the current object, and is only available inside methods.

content.text: Look at the following example:

content.code_html:
<?php
class Fruit {
  public $name;
}
$apple = new Fruit();
?>

content.text: So, where can we change the value of the $name property? There are two ways:
content.html: So, where can we change the value of the $name property? There are two ways:

content.text: 1. Inside the class (by adding a set_name() method and use $this):
content.html: 1. Inside the class (by adding a set_name() method and use $this):

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?phpclass Fruit {  public $name;  
    function set_name($name) {    $this->name = $name;  
    }}$apple = new Fruit();$apple->set_name("Apple");
    echo $apple->name;?>

content.code:
<?phpclass Fruit {  public $name;  
function set_name($name) {    $this->name = $name;
}}$apple = new Fruit();$apple->set_name("Apple");
echo $apple->name;?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<?phpclass Fruit {  public $name;  
 function set_name($name) {    $this->name = $name;  
    }}$apple = new Fruit();$apple->set_name("Apple");
 echo $apple->name;?>

content.code_html:
<?php
class Fruit {
  public $name;
  function set_name($name) {
    $this->name = $name;
  }
}
$apple = new Fruit();
$apple->set_name("Apple");

echo $apple->name;
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<?phpclass Fruit {  public $name;  
    function set_name($name) {    $this->name = $name;  
    }}$apple = new Fruit();$apple->set_name("Apple");
    echo $apple->name;?>

content.text: 2. Outside the class (by directly changing the property value):
content.html: 2. Outside the class (by directly changing the property value):

content.code_html:
<?php
class Fruit {
  public $name;
}
$apple = new Fruit();
$apple->name = "Apple";

echo $apple->name;
?>

content.text: PHP - instanceof
You can use the instanceof keyword to check if an object belongs to a specific class:
content.html: You can use the instanceof keyword to check if an object belongs to a specific class:

content.code_html:
<?php
$apple = new Fruit();
var_dump($apple instanceof Fruit);
?>
